prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI in NGC253
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Mosaic of the CI emission in NGC253 to cover its central 58"x30". Central coordinates taken from Sakamoto et al. 2011.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We want to map the CI(3P1-3P0) emission in the central disk in NGC253 which has been detected at high angular resolution (0.5-1") in several CO transitions. To cover the entire SB dominated disk and the superbubbles seen at both edges of the disk (Sakamoto et al. 2011, Bolatto et al. 2013, Krips et al., 2014), we will need 57 pointings in Nuyquist sampling to match the central 58"x30". Given that we expect extended emission larger than 5" in the channel maps, we will additionally need ACA and TP time.
Bright [CI] emission has been detected along the disk in NGC253 by Israel et al. (1995) with peak fluxes ranging between 0.5-2K in 10" large SD beams (Fig1) along the central disk. Assuming a conversion factor of 50Jy/K (JCMT), the requested angular resolution of 0.5" and a conservative uniform distribution withn 8", we expect a [CI] emission of at least 100mJy per beam. Based on the ALMA time estimator, we will need ~18s per pointing or ~17minutes on-source in total to reach an rms noise level of 20mJy at a spectral resolution of 10km/s which will be necessary to analyse the kinematics in this source at high signal-to-noise ratio (>5sigma) and resolve kinematics of GMCs (expected line width ~60km/s). In total, including overheads (<30%) and time for calibration, the requested observing time amounts to ~52minutes for the 12m-array. To match the 12m sensitivity, we will need an extra ~1.7h of total observing time with ACA and ~3.5h with TP. In total, ~4.4h are need to match the science goals for this source.
Finally, we want to note that as a free bonus we will also be able to obtain maps of the SiO, CS and Methanol emission. However, these lines have not been taken into account to derive the required sensitivities and observing times and are not regarded as crucial to reach our science goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI in NGC1068
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CI observations of NGC1068 at high angular resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We want to map the CI(3P1-3P0) emission in the central 4" in NGC1068 which has been already mapped at high angular resolution (0.5") in several CO transitions (Fig.2). To cover the circumnuclear disk which is dominated by the AGN, one pointing with the field of view of 12" in band8 will be largely sufficient.
Bright CI emission has been detected in the center of NGC1068 by Israel (2009) with peak fluxes of Ta*=250mK in 10" large SD beams (Fig1; Tmb=500mK, Ta*=0.5*Tmb). Assuming a conversion factor between S(Jy) and Ta* of 50Jy/K (JCMT), the requested angular resolution of 0.3" (=22pc) and a conservative uniform distribution within the central 5" (spectrally resolved it is probably closer to 3"), we expect a CI emission of at least 45mJy per beam. Based on the ALMA time estimator, we will need ~12minutes of on-source time to reach an rms noise level of 6mJy at a spectral resolution of 15km/s which will be necessary to analyse the kinematics in this source at high signal-to-noise ratio (>5sigma). In total, including overheads (<=30%) and time for calibration, the requested observing time amounts to ~45minutes for the 12m-array.
As opposed to NGC253 and Arp220, we won't be able to simultaneously observe SiO and CS in NGC1068 because these lines are shifted to unfavorable frequencies with poor atmospheric transmission. However, some weaker lines might be detectable for NGC1068 (e.g., C34S) but these are seen as a free bonus if detected but are not necessary to reach the science goals of this proposal.

We want to map the CI(3P1-3P0) emission in the central 4" of Arp220 which has been already mapped at high angular resolution (<=0.5") in several CO transitions (Fig.2). To cover the circumnuclear disk which is dominated by the AGN, one pointing with the field of view of 12" in band8 will be largely sufficient.
Bright CI emission has been detected in the center of Arp220 by Papadopoulos & Greve (2004) with peak fluxes ranging of ~60mK in 10" large SD beams (Fig1). Assuming a conversion factor of 50Jy/K (JCMT), the requested angular resolution of 0.23" (=90pc) and a conservative uniform distribution in the central 3", we expect a [CI] line peak fluxes of at least ~20mJy per beam. Based on the ALMA time estimator, we will need ~35minutes of on-source time to reach an rms noise level of 4mJy at a spectral resolution of 15km/s which will be necessary to analyse the kinematics in this source at high signal-to-noise ratio (>=5sigma). In total, including overheads (<=30%) and time for calibration, the requested observing time amounts to ~1.3h for the 12m-array.
Similar to NGC253, we expect to be able to detect also SiO and CS emission as a free bonus in Arp220. However, this is seen as an asset but not as crucial for the science goals of this proposal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Exploiting the new capabilities of band8 in Cycle2, we propose to map for the first time the [CI] emission in three nearby prototypical galaxies, the starburst galaxy NGC253, the Seyfert galaxy NGC1068 and the ULIRG and merger Arp220, at unprecedented subarcsecond angular resolution and sensitivity. We aim to evaluate the promising potential of [CI] emission as alternative and equal tracer to CO of the interstellar medium in our currently best templates of nearby active galaxies. How similar is the [CI] emission to that of CO in these environments? Are there differences in the [CI] properties between different activity types (NGC1068 vs. NGC253) and different star formation efficiencies (NGC253 vs. Arp220)? What are the effects of shocks onto [CI]? The proposed observations will further allow us to build up templates for the high-z galaxy population. For the latter, [CI] observations are booming thanks to increased sensitivities of current-day (sub)millimeter observatories and redshifted [CI] emission into atmospherically less constrained frequency windows.
